_meta.source: 38 CFR 3.159, Veterans Claims Assistance Act (VCAA) of 2000 (P.L. 106-475), M21-1 Adjudication Procedures Manual
_meta.authority: Code of Federal Regulations, Title 38; Public Law 106-475

overview.principle: VA has a duty to assist claimants in obtaining evidence to substantiate all substantially complete claims. VA will make reasonable efforts to help a claimant obtain evidence necessary to substantiate the claim.

federalRecords.description: VA must make as many requests as necessary to obtain relevant records from Federal departments or agencies.
recordTypes: Medical and other records from VA medical facilities
Records from non-VA facilities providing treatment at VA expense
federalRecords.standard: VA will end efforts ONLY if it concludes records do not exist or further efforts would be futile.
federalRecords.commonFailure: VA fails to request or obtain service treatment records, VA treatment records, or SSA records that are relevant to the claim.

privateRecords.description: For non-Federal records (private medical, employer, state/local), VA must make reasonable efforts: initial request plus at least one follow-up.
privateRecords.requirement: Veteran must provide authorization via VA Form 21-4142
privateRecords.commonFailure: VA sends one request and gives up, or does not inform veteran of inability to obtain records.

medicalExaminations.description: VA must provide a C&P examination or obtain a medical opinion when necessary to decide the claim.
triggerCriteria: Competent evidence of a current disability or persistent/recurrent symptoms
Evidence of an in-service event, injury, or disease
Evidence that the disability or symptoms may be associated with the in-service event
Insufficient medical evidence to make a decision
medicalExaminations.lowThreshold: The threshold for determining whether evidence 'indicates' a disability 'may be associated' with service is LOW (McLendon v. Nicholson).
medicalExaminations.commonFailure: VA does not schedule a C&P exam when one is clearly warranted by the evidence.

notification.description: VA must notify the veteran of evidence needed, evidence VA will obtain, and evidence the veteran should provide.
notification.commonFailure: VA does not properly inform veteran of what additional evidence is needed or of inability to obtain certain records.

commonFailures.description: The most frequently identified DTA errors in VA claims, ranked by frequency

errors.name: Inadequate Medical Examination or Opinion
errors.description: The C&P exam contains errors, fails to address the correct question, is based on inaccurate facts, or the examiner does not provide adequate rationale.
indicators: Examiner did not review claims file
Exam report contradicts itself
No rationale provided for negative opinion
Examiner did not address all claimed conditions
Exam based on inaccurate factual premise
Examiner did not address flare-ups or functional loss
Examiner ignored favorable medical evidence in the file
Exam was too brief or superficial for the condition's complexity
errors.remedy: Request new C&P exam or independent medical opinion

errors.name: Failure to Schedule C&P Examination
errors.description: VA fails to schedule a C&P exam or obtain a medical opinion when the evidence triggers the duty to provide one.
indicators: Current symptoms documented but no exam ordered
In-service event documented but nexus not established
Veteran requested exam but none was scheduled
Claim denied without any medical opinion
errors.remedy: File for new exam; cite McLendon low threshold standard

errors.name: Failure to Obtain Relevant Records
errors.description: VA does not request or retrieve medical, service, or private treatment records necessary for the claim.
indicators: Service treatment records not in file
VA treatment records referenced but not obtained
SSA disability records not requested
Private treatment records identified by veteran but not pursued
Only partial records obtained
errors.remedy: Identify missing records; file supplemental claim with records or request VA obtain them

errors.name: Not Addressing All Claims or Issues
errors.description: VA overlooks key issues, evidence, or implicitly raised claims.
indicators: Secondary conditions reasonably raised by evidence but not addressed
TDIU reasonably raised but not considered
Veteran filed for multiple conditions but only some were addressed
Evidence raised new theory of entitlement that was ignored
errors.remedy: File for the overlooked issues; cite the evidence that raised them

errors.name: Failure to Properly Notify Veteran
errors.description: VA does not inform veteran of what evidence is needed or that records could not be obtained.
indicators: No VCAA notice letter in file
Notice letter did not address all claimed conditions
Veteran not informed of inability to obtain records
Veteran not advised of alternative evidence sources
errors.remedy: Cite notification failure in appeal; request proper notice

errors.name: Failure to Address Medical Treatise Evidence
errors.description: Medical articles or treatise evidence submitted by the veteran is not addressed in the decision.
indicators: Veteran submitted medical literature supporting their claim
Decision does not mention or discuss the submitted evidence
Examiner's opinion contradicts submitted literature without explanation
errors.remedy: Identify the unaddressed evidence; cite the duty to address all evidence

whenDTAdoesNotApply: Higher-Level Review (HLR) — VA reviews existing evidence only, no new development
CUE claims — duty to assist does not apply to CUE motions
Supplemental claims where veteran fails to submit new and relevant evidence

remedies.ifErrorFound: When a DTA error is identified, the claim is typically remanded for correction. The VA must fix the error before making a final decision.
remedies.backPay: If a DTA error prompts VA to reconsider and grant the claim, the veteran is typically entitled to back pay for the delay caused by the error.
remedies.notCUE: Important: A duty to assist error is NOT a CUE. However, DTA errors can be raised in appeals and supplemental claims.

analysisChecklist.description: Checklist for GIA agents to evaluate potential DTA errors in a veteran's claim

steps.check: Are complete STRs and service personnel records in the file? If not, were they requested?

steps.action: Verify all VA treatment records obtained
steps.check: Are all VA treatment records from identified facilities in the file? Check for gaps in treatment history.
If veteran receives SSA disability, were those records requested? SSA records often contain relevant medical evidence.
Was a C&P exam conducted? Did the examiner review the claims file? Is the rationale adequate? Were all conditions examined? Were flare-ups and functional loss addressed?
Did the decision address ALL conditions claimed? Were secondary conditions or TDIU reasonably raised but not adjudicated?
Was the veteran properly notified of evidence needed? Were they informed of records VA could not obtain?
Did the decision discuss all relevant evidence in the file, including medical literature, buddy statements, and lay evidence?
